title: Minimum mandatory charity share
vignette: A grain-farmer must leave a corner of the field for food-relief gleaners. May the farmer keep the donation to the legal minimum (about 1.5 %) or is greater generosity expected?

options.text: Leave only the statutory minimum and keep the rest.
Contribute a larger share in line with field size and local need.

title: Early-row vs. end-row allocation
vignette: At the start of harvest the owner left several standing rows for charity but harvested everything else. Should those early rows count as the required gift, or are they treated as public pickings anyone may take?

options.text: Count them as the designated charity portion.
Treat them as fully ownerless; even the well-off may collect.

title: High-risk fruit picking
vignette: Ripe dates hang ten metres up. Must the farm owner rent a lift, harvest, and distribute the fruit safely, or can the food-relief gleaners climb and pick for themselves?

options.text: Owner must handle the hazardous harvest and pass fruit down safely.
Gleaners climb or bring ladders at their own risk; owner need not intervene.

title: “First grab” tactic
vignette: During gleaning, one person throws a tarp over a heap of loose grain and claims it all.

options.text: Let the tarp-thrower keep what was covered — first come, first served.
Confiscate and redistribute the heap so others get a share.

title: Sharp tools in gleaning scramble
vignette: To gather the leftover stalks faster, some gleaners use sickles and pruning knives, increasing the chance of injuries.

options.text: Allow any tools; speed benefits everyone.
Ban sharp tools to prevent harm.

title: Fixed time-slots for entry
vignette: Local leaders set three daily time-slots when gleaners may enter the fields. Some want open access all day.

options.text: Keep the fixed slots to reduce crowding and conflict.
Allow continuous entry to maximise opportunity.

title: Harvest before new charity law kicks in
vignette: A landowner harvested the crop before a new mandatory-donation law took effect, but the binding and packaging happens after the law begins. Must a share now be set aside?

options.text: Exempt — the critical harvesting step occurred before the law applied.
Obligated — the duty attaches at the later binding stage.

title: Crop temporarily pledged to a public trust
vignette: Grain was donated to a public food trust, then legally bought back by the farmer. Is the farmer still required to leave the statutory field margin for charity?

options.text: Yes — once repurchased, all ordinary obligations resume.
No — at the key harvesting stage the grain was trust-owned and exempt.

title: Reserving gleanings for a named recipient
vignette: A volunteer harvester gathers grain and declares: “This share is for a particular low-income neighbour.” Does that neighbour automatically gain ownership?

options.text: Yes — the collector acquires it on the neighbour’s behalf.
No — it must go to the first qualifying person encountered.

title: Ownerless only for those in need
vignette: A farmer announces, “Anyone below the poverty line may take from my orchard.” Is that selective ownerless declaration valid, or must access be equal for all?

options.text: Valid — limiting the giveaway to the needy is acceptable.
Invalid — genuine ownerlessness must be open to everyone.

title: Oversized forgotten bundle
vignette: Most bundles from a field are small, but one large four-unit bundle was left behind. Do gleaners acquire it?

options.text: Owner keeps it — too large to count as forgotten.
Poor may take it — size doesn’t matter for forgotten status.

title: Bundle left beside obvious markers
vignette: A bundle lies next to farm tools and a stone wall, suggesting the farmer meant to return. Is it still ‘forgotten’?

options.text: Not forgotten — farmer likely planned to retrieve it.
Counts as forgotten — gleaners may collect.

title: Threshold for small forgotten items
vignette: How many small forgotten bundles (or berries, flax stalks) trigger the charity right?

options.text: Two belong to the poor; three revert to the owner.
Three to the poor; four to the owner.

title: Two small bundles that equal a full stack
vignette: Two separate forgotten bundles together equal a standard full stack. Who owns the combined amount?

options.text: Owner keeps them — total volume matters.
Poor take them — each bundle was forgotten on its own.

title: Tiny plots between orchard rows
vignette: Mini-plots of grain sit between rows of olive trees. Should each micro-plot leave its own charity corner or treat the entire area as one field?

options.text: Each micro-plot must contribute separately.
One contribution for the whole area suffices.

title: Striped harvesting pattern
vignette: The farmer cuts the crop in alternating stripes, leaving moist rows to dry. Does every untouched stripe require its own donation corner?

options.text: Yes — each uncut stripe counts as a separate unit.
No — one corner for the whole field is enough.

title: Separate fresh and storage harvests
vignette: Farmer pulls fresh green onions for immediate sale but leaves the rest to dry for storage. Must a charity share be left at each picking?

options.text: Yes — each distinct harvest requires a donation.
No — only one final donation on the last harvest.

title: Seed crop vs. food crop
vignette: Onions grown only for seed sit between vegetables grown for food. Are the seed onions subject to the charity-corner rule, and does each sub-plot give separately?

options.text: Seed crop is liable; each patch must leave a share.
Seed crop is exempt, or one combined share suffices.

title: Siblings split and later re-merge farmland
vignette: Two siblings divide their inherited field. Do they each leave a charity corner separately? Later they farm jointly again — what now?

options.text: After division, each must donate; after re-merging, only one joint donation.
Always one donation — treat the estate as continuous.

title: Minimum plot size for charity duty
vignette: How small can a field be yet still fall under the mandatory food-relief corner rule? Proposals range from one square metre to ‘any size’.

options.text: Only sizeable plots are liable (various minima).
Even the tiniest plot must contribute.

title: Swapping a lost charity stalk
vignette: A stalk designated for charity accidentally falls into the farmer’s harvest pile. May the farmer substitute another stalk of equal value, or must the original be returned?

options.text: Substitution is allowed; farmer keeps his pile intact.
Must give back the very stalk that was lost.
